sn12.20:1.2: Dependent origination is the process, dependently originated phenomena are the products.
sn12.20:2.3: The principles of the Dhamma are not impermanent, since they are not things that exist. Rather, they are laws of nature that describe a process or a pattern which is always observable, so it is always true to describe it in that way. At AN 3.136 the same idea applies to impermanence, suffering and not-self. Also see Poṭṭhapāda at DN 9:31.10.
sn12.20:3.17: This phrase is also at SN 12.1:2.14. Note that there is no corresponding “dependent cessation”. The ending of dependent origination is Nibbāna, extinguishment.
sn12.20:5.2: These are called “irrational thoughts” at MN 2:7.3. These are ways of thinking driven by anxiety over the perpetuation or dissolution of the assumed Self.
